node.title: See the Real Live Man Who Grew Up in a Carnival
node.description: For our reporter, “Nightmare Alley” recalls a childhood spent working the circuit with his parents. Carnies like the World’s Smallest Woman welcomed him when cruel classmates didn’t.
node.content: ["An old-time Ferris wheel, fully lit, turns against a sinister sky. The ride is part of a traveling carnival, seemingly set up in the middle of nowhere, and a storm is coming in the form of Stan Carlisle.", "Is he man or beast?", "Come closer and find out. As the sideshow barker shouts, his voice competing with rollicking carousel music, \u201cHurry! Hurry! Hurry!\u201d", "This is \u201cNightmare Alley,\u201d a lavish noir thriller from Guillermo del Toro that arrives exclusively in theaters on Dec. 17. Bradley Cooper plays the insatiable Stan, by turns damaged drifter, aw-shucks country boy, conniving killer, society charlatan, fast-disintegrating alcoholic and primal scream. The carnival cast includes Willem Dafoe as Clem, that rasping sideshow proprietor; Rooney Mara as sweet-hearted runaway Molly, who performs as the high-voltage Electrified Girl; and Toni Collette as the weary Madam Zeena, a phony fortune teller. The action eventually moves to the upper echelons of a city, where Cate Blanchett awaits in Art Deco splendor as the bone-chilling psychiatrist Dr. Lilith Ritter.", "Everyone is conning someone, some more treacherously than others. \u201cThe carnies know they\u2019re carnies,\u201d del Toro told me. \u201cThey don\u2019t try to be anything else. It\u2019s the people in the city who pretend they are judges and philanthropists and industrialists. True rot comes when you con yourself.\u201d", "For Searchlight Pictures, which has taken the top prize at four of the last eight Oscar ceremonies, including in 2018 for \u201cThe Shape of Water,\u201d del Toro\u2019s previous film, \u201cNightmare Alley\u201d represents a breathtaking risk. It is an ultra-dark period movie that cost roughly $60 million to make, the most the studio has ever spent on a single film in its nearly 30-year history.", "But for me, \u201cNightmare Alley\u201d is something much different. Del Toro\u2019s carnival is a vivid reminder, good and bad, of my childhood.", "My parents were card-carrying carnies in the 1970s and \u201980s. They owned concession trailers \u2014 corn dogs, cotton candy, caramel apples \u2014 and traveled with a carnival to fairs in the Midwest and Canada. An early scene in \u201cNightmare Alley\u201d finds Molly, Stan and a few dozen other carnival workers eating breakfast at long tables set up under a tent. The greasy meals come from a trailer parked on one side \u2014 a \u201ccook house\u201d in carny slang. We owned one for a time. Ours had yellow \u201cflicker\u201d lights around the top. My eccentric father had a sign made for the roof that read, \u201cBurger Palace: More than 2 Dozen Sold.\u201d", "There are certainly easier occupations. Mom worked until her hands quite literally bled. We lived in an RV, sometimes without electricity. For a long time, I thought it was a dream life. Hanging out in the turning fun-house tunnel! A wild cast of characters! All the snow cones I could eat!", "People don\u2019t quite know what to say when I mention my carny past. Some are fascinated, asking if I ever encountered sideshow performers. (Read on.) Some seem horrified, judging my parents for their disregard of child labor laws. (I was dipping corn dogs in the fourth grade, sometimes working alone while our adult employees took breaks.)", "Others are puzzled, as if discovering for the first time that carnival life is real and not a Hollywood invention \u2014 a useful storytelling device for the occasional film (\u201cCarny,\u201d 1980) or television series (\u201cCarniv\u00e0le,\u201d 2003).", "To clear one thing up: Carnivals and circuses are two different things. Circuses are single, controlled shows built around animals, clowns and trapeze artists: You sit and watch. Carnivals, in contrast, have rides like the Tilt-a-Whirl and games (pop the balloon, win a prize). Carnivals have an undercurrent of rebellion \u2014 and possibly nausea, depending on whether you ride the Zipper.", "\u201cThe circus tried to preserve a feeling of grandeur and happiness while carnivals wore a dark side on their sleeve,\u201d del Toro said, noting that he is a collector of carnival memorabilia and asking whether my parents were still on the road. (They fried their last dough in 2004 after 33 years.)", "In \u201cNightmare Alley,\u201d adapted from William Lindsay Gresham\u2019s 1946 novel, Stan arrives at the carnival after a bus ride from somewhere, having done something awful to someone. He wanders the midway, captivated by the manufactured commotion, and meets some sideshow performers (\u201chuman oddities\u201d) who take him in. Zeena provides a bath. Molly gives him sparks of the romantic variety. Pete, a kindly alcoholic played by David Strathairn, teaches him a mind-reading act.", "\u201cThey can tell he\u2019s on the run, but they say look, come into our family, whatever it is, we don\u2019t care,\u201d del Toro said.", "The same was true for me. Outside the carnival \u2014 in Montana, where we lived in the off-season, and I went to school \u2014 I was an effeminate boy with a big perm (don\u2019t ask) who hated sports and adored Whitney Houston. \u201cIs it a boy or is it a girl?\u201d a school photographer once asked a teacher within my earshot. When I signed up to lip-sync \u201cHow Will I Know\u201d for the fifth-grade talent show, another teacher called me \u201cunpleasantly abnormal\u201d and sent me to the school psychologist. (Their loss. I would have killed it.)", "To them, I was the sideshow freak.", "Among the carnival crowd, it was the opposite. I was accepted, even celebrated. When I was still in grade school, my parents allowed me to roam alone when they were working, which was all the time. They knew that Slim, who ran the Ferris wheel, or Chief, the mustachioed merry-go-round operator with no teeth, or Ruby, a dwarf who performed as the World\u2019s Smallest Woman, would drop everything and eviscerate anyone who messed with me.", "\u201cThis really interesting melting pot of people \u2014 very insular, a society to itself \u2014 is one of the things that fascinates me about carnivals,\u201d del Toro said. (For Blanchett, the appeal was different: \u201cWhen I was young, I wanted to be a contortionist \u2014 you know, put your legs behind your head. To this day, magic tricks make me scream.\u201d)", "In the United States, a circus impresario, P.T. Barnum, popularized the often cruel exhibition of people with disabilities for the amusement of others \u2014 so-called freak shows or sideshows. As traveling carnivals proliferated in the 1920s and \u201930s, growing out of the 1893 Chicago World\u2019s Fair, where the Ferris wheel made its debut, these acts were offered in tents (later trailers) set up along the midway.", "Sideshows ultimately faded from carnival lineups, the result of ordinances prohibiting them and changing social mores \u2014 although some still exist, according to Marc Hartzman, author of \u201cAmerican Sideshow: An Encyclopedia of History\u2019s Most Wondrous and Curiously Strange Performers.\u201d", "In \u201cNightmare Alley,\u201d which takes place between 1939 and 1941, the Human Spider is based on an act del Toro saw at a carnival in Mexico around 1970. (He was about 6.) It involved a disturbing illusion with a person\u2019s head appearing to be attached to the hairy legs of a colossal arachnid. \u201cEven at that young age, I knew it was not a real spider body,\u201d del Toro said. \u201cBut the juxtaposition of the human head \u2014 alive, talking to me \u2014 on that body scared me so much.\u201d", "My equivalent was the Snake Lady, who was exhibited inside a brown canvas tent. \u201cDiscovered alive in the Amazon!\u201d a recording blared on a loop from a loudspeaker outside. The interior was lit by a lone red light bulb. An impossibly plump python body was coiled on top of a horizontal, waist-high platform. One end appeared to be attached to a woman\u2019s head. (The rest of her was hidden under the platform.)", "I met her a few times during her dinner break. Her name was Brandy. Once, she offered to teach me how to roll a joint. I was 9.", "Part of \u201cNightmare Alley\u201d involves a monstrous attraction known as a geek show that also existed in real life: A disheveled man sits in a pit strewn with filthy straw and bites the heads off live chickens, appearing to drink their blood. In the film \u2014 as was often the case with actual geek shows \u2014 the man is a desperate alcoholic and addict who is rewarded with liquor and narcotics.", "It\u2019s hard to watch. Fortunately, I never saw one live.", "The only other \u201cNightmare Alley\u201d film adaptation, released in 1949 and starring Tyrone Power, tried to soften the geek components of Gresham\u2019s novel. Even so, the reception was chilly. \u201cThis film traverses distasteful dramatic ground,\u201d a critic for The New York Times wrote. (The picture has recently been reappraised by some as a captivating example of classic noir.)", "Del Toro holds nothing back.", "\u201cTo honor Gresham\u2019s novel, especially that ending, we had to go all the way into the abyss,\u201d he said.", "In other words, don\u2019t come looking for \u201cShape of Water\u201d hopefulness. There isn\u2019t any. Besides, del Toro added, the darkness of the source material aligned with his personal dismay over extremism in the current culture. \u201cWe have this appetite for being lifted out of reality even by the most impossible hucksterism,\u201d he said. \u201cWe\u2019re willing to be lied to and accept it.\u201d Or as Blanchett put it, \u201cIt\u2019s such an interesting examination of lies. The lies one tells oneself. The lies one tells in public.\u201d", "\u201cNightmare Alley\u201d also lacks fantasy, a hallmark of del Toro\u2019s work from the eyeballs-on-his-palms Pale Man in \u201cPan\u2019s Labyrinth\u201d (2006) to the smoky ghosts of \u201cCrimson Peak\u201d (2015), not to mention the \u201cShape of Water\u201d human-amphibian river god.", "As J. Miles Dale, who produced \u201cNightmare Alley\u201d with del Toro and Cooper, explained, \u201cThis film is all naturalism. It really needed that v\u00e9rit\u00e9 feel.\u201d", "To that end, the producers decided to build a carnival outdoors instead of on a soundstage, something del Toro called \u201ca big, big, big decision.\u201d Dale tracked down a 1917 Ferris wheel, a 1931 carousel and other period rides and signage.", "They set up at a rural fairgrounds in Canada \u2014 after burying 1,000 feet of irrigation pipe in the dirt so that del Toro could have the right consistency of mud. (\u201cThat request woke the studio up, for sure,\u201d Dale said.) They then had to abandon the set for more than six months because the pandemic halted production. By the time they returned, he added, \u201ceverything had become sort of gritty and aged, which was sort of perfect.\u201d", "Fair enough. I never met a carny with clean fingernails."]
